ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basics necessary for corporate capital structuring
corporate capital structure, debt financing, equity financing, financial crises, banking, moral hazard, etc.
This course taught me a lot theoretical/economic concepts behind corporate finance.
A lot of basics for finance and accounting.
learnt a lot about corporate finance, very useful knowledge, content is interesting and applicable
General theory of corporate finance.
Not actually that much, related to debt offerings, equity issuances, things like that but I learned much more prepping for banking interviews than I did from this class
I learned a lot about how companies finance operations and how they use debt and resources to their advantage.
Substantial understanding of the basics of corporate finance. Glad i took this.
I learned the basics of corporate finance and the theory behind a lot of key frameworks.

debt vs. equity capital structures, debt vs. equity issuance, Modigliani-Miller, debt overhang, asymmetric information, CEO agency problems, payout policy and dividends, debt multiplicity, risk management, bankruptcy, banking, bailouts and moral hazard, the 2008 financial crisis, CAPM, valuing a corporation (Discounting Cash Flows), leasing, mergers & acquisitions

I learned about discounted cash flows, agency problems, debt dilution and overhang, bank runs & moral hazards, calculating free cash flows for leasing vs. buying (and true tax vs. non-tax leases), and the financial crisis.
I learned about the mathematical theory behind corporate finance
A lot about finance.
Good basic understanding of firm capital structure and how this translates into the kind of decisions that managers and stakeholders make.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There'd be times some advanced terms were used and I'd be confused, could be some better explanation on terms/acronyms
Professor Clayton speaks slowly but has really good slides

Strength: amazingly useful material for someone going into finance
Weakness: the pace is a bit fast

The strength of this course is that it teaches you a lot of conceptual corporate finance through many theoretical applications. The weakness is that it doesn't cover very real-world, mathematical topics the way you would approach them in the finance industry.

Pros
- The Median grade hovers around A / A -
- Lectures are optional and recordings are available online.
- Homework is manageable. There are 4 problem sets. These a graded primarily on completion (on a scale of 0 - 3). There is sufficient handholding during office hours. If you attend, you will get the max 3 points.
- Prof. Clayton is a great instructor. He is lucid and goes over the lecture content slowly.

Cons.
-This is not a hands-on finance class. It is very theoretical and there is a lot of algebra. 
-There is a lot of lecture material. In some lectures, you are introduced to a new formula/model every 5 slides. 
-The exams are closed book, so be prepared to cram all the formulas/models.

It was a very general course that covered a bit of each topic within corporate finance and banking. I really like the topics covered. The psets were a bit difficult and long but very helpful for understanding the material.

strength: content is interesting and useful 
weakness: wish there were more psets so that we can understand the material better; exam does not reflect pset well; too few office hour provided; section is not too helpful

It was relatively interesting conceptually but very theoretical and the course went sort of slow. The concepts were explained with examples with a lot of exogenous variables that would be listed at the beginning but I would forget them so It would be confusing where certain numbers were coming from
professor should work through problems on the board to show you really how to do them, just lecturing off a PowerPoint isnt very helpful

Strength: Well organized with a logical order for learning content and made learning each new concept easier and more interesting. 
Weakness: Course content was highly theoretical and did not feel applicable enough to the real world. Wish Professor Clayton would change the curriculum because it seemed like most students did not enjoy how theoretical it was.
Strengths was using real life examples and use of powerpoints, also having a good TF helped a lot.
The material was interesting and Professor Clayton was kind, but his lectures were sometimes dry.

Professor Clayton was a strong lecturer of topics and a clear explainer of concepts. The structure/organization of the class, as well as each individual lectures, was fantastic. It was very easy to follow along. The material was sometimes dry upon first glance, but completing the Problem Sets and studying for the exams made me better appreciate the importance of corporate finance.

Strengths: Professor and TA's are very approachable and helpful if you need extra help. Problem sets are helpful and since they're graded on completion not too stressful. Weaknesses: lecture notes could be clearer - often, the examples are way too long and it can be difficult to ascertain what is meant as interesting side material versus what will be on the exams - if Prof. Clayton could streamline the lectures and maybe make the examples more general and to the point, that would be a great improvement.

Strengths: interesting content, responsive professor 

Weaknesses: Answer keys for homework and past exams were sometimes difficult to understand

Strength: very broad coverage of many important finance topics.
Weakness: not really applicable to real life finance.
Fairly clear content, though lectures could be somewhat dry and very few problem sets throughout the semester

The course does a good job of educating you very well on certain key tenets of capital structure and how they relate to each other (such as the relationship between debt and equity). This is highlighted through scenario based exercises.

The course sometimes oversimplified nuances, and could do a better job of relating our simplified models to the real world.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yeah, interesting enough
If you are doing Investment Banking or Finance, the class is pretty important
Absolutely
I would recommend this course despite it not being perfect. There are no other corporate finance courses at Yale and I would rather take this one than none if you are planning to work in finance.
Yes! It is general and a good foundational class to take for finance/banking.
yes, if you like finance
If you are willing to put in extra time and effort into understanding everything, I would recommend it. The grading is also pretty lax.

Honestly no. If youre interested in finance take another course or save it for learning in summer internships. This class is boring to sit through so attendance dwindles (literally 8 ppl of a 70 person class showed up regularly). There are only four psets so you arent really held accountable for knowing the material. Its one of those classes where you either are terribly lost or you think its insanely easy and theres no in between.
Yes, if interested in business or finance, this course is very helpful.
Yes
Yes, I would recommend this to anyone planning on working in finance.

I think this class is a must-take for anyone entering the world of finance post-graduation. The concepts covered are table stakes for a career in finance. The workload is exceedingly manageable, the topics are generally interesting, and the Professor is very strong. Sometimes the class felt like a barrage of debt, debt, debt -- but you learn that not all debt (or equity) is created equal.
It's not really too helpful for the practical purpose of landing an internship, but it is still interesting.
Yes, it is a great way to learn about corporate finance with a professor who is knowledgeable and willing to answer students questions
Great econ elective
Yes, it is a good course AFTER you take financial economics or have some finance background. Not good for banking interviews not going to lie. The 400 guide is your best bet.

Depends. If they're interested in corporate finance in particular, then sure. Otherwise, they might find that there's a bit too much in terms of specific  models, etc, that might not be helpful or relevant elsewhere
Yes, for those interested in understanding financial incentives behind firms and some private sector economics.
